<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_close_error:
```c
static void
connection_close_error (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                        const char *emsg)
{
  connection->stop_with_error = true;
  connection->discard_request = true;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (NULL != emsg)
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              "%s\n",
              emsg);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) emsg; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  MHD_connection_close_ (connection,
                         MHD_REQUEST_TERMINATED_WITH_ERROR);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided fragment. The code contains only standard C constructs: a static function, pointer to a struct parameter, preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef/#else/#endif), a cast to void to silence an unused-parameter warning, assignment to structure members, and a function call. There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm, __builtin_*, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, asm labels, trailing commas in expressions, or other vendor-specific tokens typically documented as extensions. The macro MHD_DLOG may expand to logging code (possibly a variadic macro), but variadic macros are part of standard C (since C99) and a macro expansion itself is not a language extension unless it uses extension-specific constructs — none are visible here. The use of true/false likely comes from stdbool.h or project-defined macros; that is not inherently a compiler language extension. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 in this snippet.
